verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD when King Zedekiah sent Pashhur son of Malchiah and Zephaniah the priest, son of Maaseiah, to him, saying:
verses.comment: This begins a new prophecy specifically addressing King Zedekiah’s appeal. The presence of both a royal official and a priest underscores Jeremiah's role in speaking God's will to both civil and religious authorities.

verses.text: "Please ask the LORD for us, for Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon is attacking us. Perhaps the LORD will deal with us by His wondrous deeds, so that he will withdraw from us."
verses.comment: Zedekiah seeks a miraculous deliverance similar to past rescues. The appeal echoes earlier pleas in Israel’s history, showing hope in God’s intervention through signs and wonders.

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to them, "Thus you shall say to Zedekiah:
verses.comment: Jeremiah delivers God's reply, acting as a channel of God’s authoritative message, demonstrating the prophet's unique mediation—a theme central to many later interpretations of spiritual authority.

verses.text: "Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: 'Look, I will turn back the weapons of war that you have in your hands, with which you fight against the king of Babylon and the Chaldeans who are besieging you outside the walls, and I will gather them into the center of this city.
verses.comment: God declares He will thwart their defense, turning their weapons against themselves—a divine judgment reminiscent of covenant curses for disobedience.

verses.text: I Myself will fight against you with an outstretched hand and with a strong arm, in anger, fury, and great wrath.
verses.comment: The language of 'outstretched hand' usually signals deliverance (Ex. 6:6) but here is inverted to signal judgment. Highlights God's sovereign intervention, typologically foreshadowing judgment and mercy motifs in salvation history.

verses.text: I will strike down the inhabitants of this city, both man and beast; they shall die by a great plague.
verses.comment: Plague serves as an instrument of divine judgment, paralleling the plagues against Egypt. The judgment is comprehensive—affecting all life within Jerusalem.

verses.text: "Afterwards," declares the LORD, "I will give Zedekiah king of Judah, his officials, and the people left in this city—those who survive the plague, sword, and famine—into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, into the hand of their enemies, and into the hand of those who seek their lives. He will strike them down with the edge of the sword; he will not pity them, nor spare them, nor have compassion."
verses.comment: No escape is possible; God gives His people over to the consequences of their rebellion. Notice how mercy is withheld—heightening the drama of later restoration promises.

verses.text: "And to this people you shall say: ‘Thus says the LORD: See, I am placing before you the way of life and the way of death.
verses.comment: God’s mercy remains available: an explicit choice is offered, reflecting earlier covenant themes and prefiguring deeper spiritual choices in Christian life (Deut. 30:19).

verses.text: Those who stay in this city will die by sword, famine, and plague; but those who go out and surrender to the Chaldeans who are besieging you will live, and they will escape with their lives.
verses.comment: The radical choice: survival comes not through arms but submission. Foreshadows deeper spiritual truths—the paradox of losing one’s life to save it (Luke 9:24).

verses.text: For I have set My face against this city for harm and not for good," declares the LORD. "It will be given into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will burn it with fire."
verses.comment: Judgment is certain; God’s face against the city reflects direct opposition. Burning with fire points to total destruction but spiritually foreshadows the purifying work of later restoration.

verses.text: "And to the house of the king of Judah say: 'Hear the word of the LORD.
verses.comment: Direct address to the house of David emphasizes the ongoing call to righteousness and faithfulness—an important theme with spiritual implications for Christian understandings of kingship and leadership.

verses.text: O house of David, thus says the LORD: ‘Execute justice in the morning, and rescue the one who is robbed from the hand of his oppressor, lest My wrath go forth like fire and burn, with no one to quench it, because of your evil deeds.’
verses.comment: The Davidic house is repeatedly charged to act justly. This justice motif echoes Messianic expectations and sets a spiritual precedent for ongoing Christian witness (see Ps. 72:4).

verses.text: "Behold, I am against you, O inhabitant of the valley, rock of the plain," declares the LORD, "you who say, ‘Who shall come down against us, or who shall enter our dwellings?’
verses.comment: False security in physical location is warned against. The ‘rock of the plain’ reflects misplaced confidence, a recurring theme in both testaments regarding reliance on God rather than worldly strength.

verses.text: I will punish you according to the fruit of your deeds," declares the LORD. "I will kindle a fire in its forest, and it shall consume all that is around it."
verses.comment: Divine retribution accords with deeds—a theme that resonates throughout the biblical testimony (Ps. 62:12, Jer. 17:10) and suggests both the justice and opportunity for repentance imaged in later spiritual traditions.
